history.content:
I haven't taken this combination, but I have taken 54 and 61C and have friends who have taken 16A. EE16A + Math 54 is a decent combination that synchronises well, and while 16A and 61C are both high workload classes, 54 is a decent technical to add to that combination. It should be doable :)

--

I haven't taken CS 61C but echoing the above answer, EE  16A and Math 54 work very well together and much of the linear algebra (which takes up about 2/3 of the 16A material) overlaps with Math 54. Being exposed to the material twice in different contexts may be of help if you don't consider yourself a math-y person. I don't think the workload will be impossible, but it will be a decent amount of work from what I hear about CS61C.

I haven't taken this combination, but I have taken 54 and 61C and have friends who have taken 16A. EE16A + Math 54 is a decent combination that synchronises well, and while 16A and 61C are both high workload classes, 54 is a decent technical to add to that combination. It should be doable :)

Why are you doing this? For CS students, the strong recommendation is 16A+16B rather than 54+16B and 16A+54 is really the worst choice of the lot. 

It would be far better to just do 16A+61C and use your units for other courses that advance your interests.

children.subject: Well I hear they are trying to get other departments to take EE16AB as a replacement for 54, so you may not have to take it.
Thanks for the info. Do you remember where you heard that?

Elad Alon: For any incoming freshman who are reading this, I would like to strongly re-emphasize Anant's suggestion above that EE16A + EE16B is for the large majority of you the best overall plan.  For incoming freshman, the only two options will be 16A + 16B, or Math 54 + 16B.  The latter option however will require some self-learning of the circuits content from 16A, and while we will be making resources available to help with that (please see the posts/response in this thread), unless you are planning to potentially major in something that specifically requires math 54, there really isn't a benefit to taking that approach.  I'd like to also note that we are in the process of actively reaching out to other departments to make it so that they will accept 16A+16B as an alternative to math 54 (for both prerequisites and majors); if anyone has a specific major/department they'd like to make sure we reach out to on that front, please feel free to contact me.

This is in @3372
Not OP, but if I'm considering a Stat or Math minor, should I do 54/16B or is there still value in taking 54, 16A, and 16B?

history.content:
Has anyone done this combo, and if so how was it / any tips? I wouldn't consider myself super strong at math, and this is really math-heavy.

This is the only combo I think I can work out for this semester to graduate on time... I'm undeclared CS/CogSci and won't declare until summer, and I just saw the thing about non-declared people getting dropped from the waitlist after phase 1 & it kinda screwed up my plans :(
history.subject: EE 16A + 61C + Math 54?
